Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Individualized Ventilation in Frail Patients Undergoing Non-Cardiac Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: Sixty-one frail patients aged ≥65 years scheduled for elective non-cardiac surgery were randomized

Participants.evidence: frail patients aged ≥65 years scheduled for elective non-cardiac surgery

Intervention.evidence: individualized PEEP group received PEEP titrated to minimize driving pressure, while the standard PEEP group received a fixed PEEP of 5 cmH2O

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the impact of driving pressure-guided individualized ventilation compared to standard positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) ventilation on PPCs in frail patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of PPCs within 7 days postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomization was based on a pre-established allocation list

Blinding.evidence: outcome assessors were blinded to group assignments

Number_Randomised.evidence: Sixty-one frail patients aged ≥65 years scheduled for elective non-cardiac surgery were randomized to either the individualized PEEP group (n=31) or the standard PEEP group (n=30).

Result_Outcome.evidence: No PPCs occurred in the individualized PEEP group, whereas 7 patients (23.3%) in the standard PEEP group developed PPCs (p<0.01).
